examples.title: Example 1: HTML without CSS
examples.html:

examples.explanation:
This example shows a basic HTML document without any CSS applied. Notice how the browser applies its default styles:

- The heading is larger and bolder than regular text
- The unordered list has bullet points
- The paragraph has some spacing around it
- The button has a default appearance

While functional, the page lacks visual appeal and brand identity. It uses only the browser's default styling, which varies between different browsers. This highlights why CSS is necessary for creating professional and consistent web experiences.

examples.title: Example 2: Adding Basic CSS
examples.html:
Welcome to My Website

This is a paragraph of text on a webpage with basic CSS styling applied.

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Item 3
examples.explanation:
This example demonstrates the same HTML structure, but with CSS applied. Notice the dramatic visual difference:

1. **Typography improvements**:
   - The font is now Arial (or a sans-serif alternative) instead of the browser's default
   - Text sizes and spacing are optimized for better readability
   - The heading is colored and underlined to make it stand out

2. **Layout enhancements**:
   - The page has margins to prevent content from touching the edges
   - The list has proper spacing and a background to distinguish it

3. **Visual styling**:
   - Colors are used strategically to create visual hierarchy
   - The button is styled to look more appealing and interactive
   - Hover effects provide feedback when users interact with elements

This demonstrates CSS's power to transform the same HTML content into a more visually appealing and user-friendly experience.

examples.title: Example 3: CSS and the Box Model
examples.html:
Understanding the CSS Box Model

Every HTML element is a box with content, padding, border, and margin.

Box 1
Box 2
Box 3
examples.explanation:
This example introduces some key concepts about how CSS controls layout and spacing through the CSS Box Model:

1. **The CSS Box Model**:
   Every HTML element is treated as a rectangular box with four layers:
   - Content: The actual content of the element (text, images, etc.)
   - Padding: Space between the content and border
   - Border: The line that surrounds the padding
   - Margin: Space outside the border that separates elements from each other

2. **Layout Control**:
   - The `.container` class centers content and sets a maximum width
   - The `.content-boxes` class uses flexbox to create a row of equally spaced boxes
   - Each box has defined dimensions, colors, and spacing

3. **Visual Design**:
   - Border radius creates rounded corners
   - Box shadow adds depth
   - Color is used to differentiate elements

This example demonstrates how CSS not only styles individual elements but also controls how they relate to each other in the layout. The box model is fundamental to understanding how spacing works in CSS.

examples.title: Example 4: Responsive Design with CSS
examples.html:
Responsive Design with CSS

CSS enables websites to adapt to different screen sizes, from mobile phones to large desktop monitors.

Mobile First

Design for mobile devices first, then enhance for larger screens.

Fluid Layouts

Use relative units like percentages instead of fixed pixel values.

Media Queries

Apply different styles based on device characteristics.

Resize your browser window to see how the layout adapts!
examples.explanation:
This example demonstrates how CSS enables responsive web design, allowing a website to adapt to different screen sizes:

1. **Mobile-First Approach**:
   - The default styles are for mobile devices (smallest screens)
   - Media queries add enhancements for larger screens
   - This ensures the site works on all devices, even if advanced CSS features aren't supported

2. **Responsive Layout Techniques**:
   - **Fluid containers**: Using percentages and max-width to control layout width
   - **Flexible layouts**: Using Flexbox to create adaptive layouts
   - **Media queries**: Applying different styles based on screen width
   - **Relative units**: Using rem and percentages instead of fixed pixel values

3. **Breakpoints**:
   - Mobile: Default layout (cards stacked vertically)
   - Tablet (768px+): Two cards in the first row, one card below
   - Desktop (1024px+): All three cards in one row

Responsive design is one of the most important applications of CSS in modern web development. It allows websites to provide optimal viewing experiences across a wide range of devices, from smartphones to desktop monitors, without creating separate versions for each device type.

examples.title: Example 5: CSS for Visual Effects and User Experience
examples.html:
Visual Effects with CSS

CSS can create engaging visual effects and improve user experience.

Hover to see transform

CSS Animation

Text Styling with CSS

Text with shadow effect

Text with gradient effect

This paragraph has a fancy first letter, demonstrating how CSS can be used for typographical effects.
examples.explanation:
This example demonstrates how CSS can create visual effects that enhance user experience and engagement:

1. **Interactive Elements**:
   - **Button with states**: The button changes appearance on hover and when clicked, providing visual feedback to users
   - **Transition effects**: Smooth property changes when users interact with elements
   - **Transform effects**: Changing an element's size, rotation, or position for visual interest
   - **Animations**: Continuous movement that draws attention to important elements

2. **Text Effects**:
   - **Text shadows**: Adding depth and emphasis to text
   - **Gradient text**: Creating visually interesting multi-colored text
   - **Drop cap**: Styling the first letter differently for visual interest

3. **CSS Techniques Demonstrated**:
   - **Pseudo-classes**: `:hover` and `:active` for interaction states
   - **Transitions**: For smooth property changes
   - **Transforms**: For changing element appearance
   - **Animations**: Using `@keyframes` to define animation sequences
   - **Pseudo-elements**: `::first-letter` to target specific parts of text

These visual effects are a crucial part of modern web design. They provide feedback to users, make interfaces more intuitive, and create more engaging experiences. CSS makes these effects possible without requiring JavaScript or images, improving performance and accessibility.
